body:
Thanks for your quick response!

One more question. Is it possible to add weights for each output of each sample? So that different samples are used for different loss. One sample doesn't contribute to the loss of a output unit when the corresponding weight is zero.
Do I need to recompile anything?
Yes, you will need to rebuild libmxnet.so, and re-install the python.

Yes, this is possible. It is not supported by current symbolic operators, however, we can create a new loss function that accepts the weight(1 length tensor as argument) and customize that behavior.

If the weight is very non-uniform(say, on scale of [0,100] ), it is not going to work, as SGD is not very good at deal with non uniformly scaled gradient, randomly drop the examples by probability weight might be a better idea
The multi loss is already supported in the symbolic API, the question is more on what can be done to make it easily available in the fit function.

Yes, the weights shoud fall into a reasonable range or there might be optimization problems.

The weights can be useful when there are missing labels. One can still use all the samples and each sample contributes to a loss only when it has the corresponding label.

It can also help in case of unbalanced training set. When there are fewer samples for one class, one may want to assign larger weights to them.

In a word, the weights will be useful in maintaining balance both between samples and between losses.
BTW, how can it be achieved that model be saved every k iterations? Currently I save a check point after each iteration.
modify this https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/callback.py#L12 add a period parameter (with default=1)

It was trying to allocate 73 GB, and I cap out at 32 GB; I'm somewhat surprised, though, as it only looked like it was taking up 16 GB when I loaded them all as numpy arrays.  I suppose  I'm going to have to do segmentation instead of trying to feed them in as is; thank you for the diagnostic help.

Re: the original question, is there an existing tool for computing the image mean, or do I need to build that utility?

The image iterator will automatically calculate/load mean file if you set `mean_file=mean.nd`. Personally, I set `mean_r=117`, `mean_g=117`, `mean_b=117` instead of such a mean file. There is no performance hurt.

The checkpoint ndarrays are all on CPU, so you should be able to load them back.
I am not aware of the problem your mentioned in asnumpy, it would be nice if you can help provide more information. For example, Is the error reproducible? , what is the size of memory copy when the memcpy happend etc.

You can make local modification to the project, either reinstall the python, or simply add path to mxnet/python to python path so the recompiled project directly take effect

Thanks!
should be fixed by #385
cc @antinucleon @mli

Oh, my fault.
solved by make clean && make

Is there a GPU equivalent line for the requested CPU memory? Just to make sure I could get it working, I resized all my images to 256x256; even with a batch size of 2, it's throwing 

```
mxnet.base.MXNetError: [10:57:24] src/storage/./gpu_device_storage.h:39: Check failed: e == cudaSuccess || e == cudaErrorCudartUnloading CUDA: out of memory
```

The fully loaded 256x256 takes up 1.6 GB or so of CPU RAM, and my GPU is a titan X, so it seems unlikely that it genuinely can't find the memory for that.  I've also tried converting to greyscale (1x512x512), although it seemed to have difficulty loading it.
@mli Thanks!

I was looking at saving and loading JSON interface today. Since the JSON encoding and decoding is completely handled in the libmxnet backend, it seems there is no need to reverse the shape, and the saved json should be able to load correctly from any language binding. However, this also means that the users are discouraged to manually edit the JSON file unless he knows what he is doing.

Model parameter is about 500Mb, gpu is tesla k40 with 11519MiB. os is CentOS
Regarding the first question: does it mean I need to copy my parameter to cpu ndarrays before storing them? 

For the ndarray crash problem, I have tried to rebuild the code (with gcc 4.8.5 and gcc 4.9 for the previous version) and run it again, but it still produce the same result. But I Don't have this problem on a Ubuntu 4.8.2 machine.
Yes, that is what I mean, if user need to implement a visualization of nets in the native side, he need to remember to reverse the shape

I met the same problem.
(In the file include/mxnet/c_api.h from line 16 to line 18, remove "__cdecl".)
i.e. change from
"
#define MXNET_DLL MXNET_EXTERN_C __cdecl __declspec(dllexport)
#else
#define MXNET_DLL MXNET_EXTERN_C __cdecl __declspec(dllimport)
"
to
"
#define MXNET_DLL MXNET_EXTERN_C __declspec(dllexport)
#else
#define MXNET_DLL MXNET_EXTERN_C __declspec(dllimport)
"

Hope this will help.
hmm @hjk41 Can you look into this? Maybe the __cdel is not needed here?
Yes! This is something we should do
I will close this issue for now, please feel free to reopen it if there is future questions on this thread
You will need to preshuffle the list before you pack the file.
The multi label softmax is merged in #387

If you mean optimization algorithm, look for optimizer

Thanks for your reply. We could say it's a new optimization algorithm. I want to change the way network forwards the data and backwards garden. How does mxnet do the forward and backward? Is there any documents about it?
You are looking for symbolic execution API http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/symbol_in_pictures.html

The json file was not meant to be edited manually. Instead the symbolic API can be used to load things in and compose these structures. For configuration files, if we want something related, we might want to support a more readable format
If the parameters are returned by fit, they are already in CPU, so you don't have to copy them. If you are training using low level interface, then probably you need to do the copy

There is no limit on how much memory to get. As everything is cutting the edge of memory, maybe you can check the memory requested, maybe the input size is indeed too large for this configuration(it was used for cifar, which means it expects a small input size). Try to use the one for imagenet, which might solve your probem
Is it tested on windows?
https://github.com/Yangqing/caffe2/blob/master/caffe/proto/caffe.proto
yes,but,must merage https://github.com/dmlc/ps-lite/pull/22 first in ps-lite

Thanks @sxjscience, for the great summary!

On Mon, Oct 26, 2015 at 4:18 PM, sxjscience notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @hjk41 https://github.com/hjk41 I've faced similar problem as @yunge
> https://github.com/yunge and the new version fixes the issue. Now I'm
> able to compile and run MXNet on Windows (Only CPU).
> 
> I use Intel Parallel Studio Xe 2016 + VS2013 + OpenCV3.0 + Canopy. The
> cmake command should be like cmake -DOpenCV_DIR=YOUR_OPENCV_DIR
> -DBLAS=MKL .. and the resulting VS2013 project should be configured to 64
> bit. Also, to make the python package find the dll, the dll path
> generation code
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/libinfo.py#L18-L29
> should be changed accordingly. Moreover, since EPD has a pre-install openmp
> library that conflicts with the new MKL, I use the solution described here
> https://github.com/JoFrhwld/FAVE/wiki/Troubleshooting-FAVE-extract.
> 
> Hope my experience can help others who are installing MXNet on Windows.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/386#issuecomment-151056975.

## 

HONG Chuntao
System Research Group
Microsoft Research Asia

Hi, @hjk41 , everything is ok now, with openblas/cuda7.5, thanks!

I've created [CPU](https://hub.docker.com/r/kaixhin/mxnet/) and [CUDA](https://hub.docker.com/r/kaixhin/cuda-mxnet/) Docker images - the source and documentation is [here](https://github.com/Kaixhin/dockerfiles). If these are suitable then you can add them to the docs or I can do it and submit a PR.

I've only done basic tests - running a [MNIST example](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/mnist/mlp.py) and [creating a GPU array](http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/R-package/ndarrayAndSymbolTutorial.html#ndarray-vectorized-tensor-computations-on-cpus-and-gpus), so you probably will want to do more.

Thanks Micheal! You should be able to dump out json file directly from python. For example in composite_symbol.ipynb  before plot, you can do 

``` python
in3a.save("in3a.json")
```

I only have my work laptop and can't install Mxnet on it (because of the dependencies).
That's why I can't try the Python version for instance.

I have read that a binary version of R package for windows is planed.
Do you know if there is something somewhere I can try?

Kind regards,
Michaël

Try this https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases Should give you python verison.

For R, I think you can try type `R CMD INSTALL R-package` after you finish the binary install, but it has not been fully tested

@tqchen Thank you for this link, I will try it.

BTW, in input fields, there are always an ID and a 0, any idea of the meaning of the 0s?

``` JSON
"inputs": [[4, 0], [5, 0], [6, 0]], 
```
It is a pair, (4, 0) means input from node 4's first output(0 based index)

Hi Kaixhin,

That an awesome news. Can you put instructions in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/build.md and add a link in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet#contents (probably on the same line with Installation)

on the multiple gpus case, each gpu computes the gradient for batch_size / num_gpu examples in an iteration, then gradient are aggregated by communication. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/developer-guide/multi_node.md#multiple-devices-on-a-single-machine

cc @antinucleon

A slight difference from numpy, `mx.nd.norm` returns a 1D ndarray on the same device as source tensor. Need

``` python
a = mx.nd.array(src)
scalar = a.asscalar()
```

This was not yet possible, but is an interesting feature to add to. 
I think what can be done is add timing function to
-  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/symbol/graph_executor.cc#L235
  And record time info into op_node here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/symbol/graph_executor.cc#L218

It would really be great if you like to take a look and add this :)
Thanks @tqchen, I'll try that.

Not sure why it happens. Maybe ICC is not fully compatible with latest C++ features yet?

@RishabGargeya It would be great if you can use an example dataset (either randomly generated numpy array, or mnist) that reproduce the problem, so we can help you better by looking into what is going on. Thanks.

Torch's upsampling implementation is [here](https://github.com/torch/nn/blob/master/SpatialUpSamplingNearest.lua) and [here](https://github.com/torch/nn/blob/master/generic/SpatialUpSamplingNearest.c).

The corresponding concepts in Caffe are [net](https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/blob/master/src/caffe/net.cpp), [solver](https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/blob/master/src/caffe/solver.cpp) and [solvers](https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/tree/master/src/caffe/solvers). Caffe has merged the parallel features in https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/pull/2870 and https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/pull/2903. Distributed training was [published](https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/pull/3252) by @cque7 from Intel yesterday.

I think explicit solver is unnecessary. In my view model is for ppl don't have any customize requirement. Symbolic interface is better for customized need. Also we are not making an extra caffe, if there is performance consideration we welcome to have benchmark,

I guess @piiswrong is talking about potential re-use of some components in model for other types of purposes. This requirement is reasonable. I can see two possible ways to do this:
- Do this after RNN model into mxnet/python, look for common components after wards
- @piiswrong Can propose a PR on this, with an implementation of auto-encoder, to show there can be case for code reuse

@piiswrong I think the headache part for RNN model is hidden states. I will make an attention model tomorrow or the day after tomorrow, then I believe we will have a better sense of how to reuse current code.

@antinucleon we can debate about whether solvers are necessary, but I think FeedForwardModel/Model separation is a good idea. Without a base model class, you need to write save/load for every custom model to say the least. There are also stuff like listing/allocating parameter that can be reused. 

This is also going to be bad for creating a pretrained model repo in the future, since you have to sed weights along with code to load them.
